intro: Disa auriculata, commonly known as the golden orchid, is a striking member of the Orchidaceae family native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its vivid yellow petals and a distinctive, auricle-like appendage on the lower lip of its flower. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, attracting various pollinators such as bees and birds. Disa auriculata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also valued in traditional medicine for its purported healing properties.
